title: 115_hr1539
content: The Act is titled the "Early Hearing Detection and Intervention Act of 2017". Congress finds that deaf and hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, and young children require specialized early intervention programs to reach their full potential. Families benefit from comprehensive early intervention programs that support their child's development in all areas. Best practices for early intervention include language acquisition, family support, and progress monitoring. Effective hearing screening and early intervention programs are essential to identify hearing levels in deaf and hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, and young children for timely access to appropriate interventions. SEC. 3. REAUTHORIZATION OF PROGRAM FOR EARLY DETECTION, DIAGNOSIS, AND TREATMENT REGARDING DEAF AND HARD-OF-HEARING NEWBORNS, INFANTS, AND YOUNG CHILDREN. Section 399M of the Public Health Service Act is amended to focus on early detection, diagnosis, and treatment for deaf and hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, and young children. The Health Resources and Services Administration will award grants to develop statewide programs for hearing screening, diagnosis, and intervention for newborns, infants, and young children, as well as to train qualified personnel and healthcare providers. The Health Resources and Services Administration will award grants for early intervention programs for deaf or hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, and young children, including language acquisition interventions and family support. This includes referral to specialized programs under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act to meet their unique communication needs. The program aims to provide accurate and evidence-based information to parents for decision-making regarding assistive hearing technologies and communication modalities. It also includes mechanisms for family support and technical assistance to states through resource centers. To further enhance State early hearing detection and intervention programs, efficient models are being identified or developed to ensure deaf or hard-of-hearing newborns, infants, and young children receive follow-up by qualified providers and referrals to early intervention services. State agencies are encouraged to increase the rate of follow-up and referral. Technical assistance, data management, and applied research are also provided. The Secretary will provide grants for technical assistance, data tracking systems, and applied research related to newborn, infant, and young childhood hearing screening and intervention services through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The grants provided by the Secretary will support applied research, technical assistance, monitoring, and coordination of data management for newborn, infant, and young childhood hearing screening and intervention programs. The grants provided by the Secretary support technical assistance, data collection, and research on newborn, infant, and young childhood hearing screening programs. The curr_chunk focuses on research objectives related to congenital hearing loss, screening effectiveness, and data integration for early hearing loss. The curr_chunk discusses the exchange of information between clinical care and public health, focusing on research and development of new screening techniques for hearing loss. Coordination and collaboration between different health agencies are emphasized in carrying out programs related to early hearing loss detection. The Administration, CDC Director, and NIH Director collaborate with other federal, state, and local agencies for early intervention services related to maternal and child health, Medicaid, and children's health insurance programs. The curr_chunk discusses various groups involved in serving individuals who are deaf and hard-of-hearing, including consumer groups, national medical organizations, individuals and families, and qualified professionals proficient in deaf and hard-of-hearing children's language. The curr_chunk focuses on coordinating policy recommendations for newborn and infant hearing screening with federal and state levels, private sector, and professional organizations. The curr_chunk discusses the coordination between the Health Resources and Services Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to assist states in establishing hearing screening programs for newborns, infants, and young children, as well as developing data collection systems. It also mentions that state laws regarding hearing screening for children should not be preempted. The curr_chunk defines "audiologic" evaluation procedures for assessing auditory system status, identifying hearing disorders, determining treatment options, and linking to appropriate programs. The curr_chunk discusses early intervention services for children who are deaf or hard-of-hearing, including medical evaluation, hearing aid assessment, audiologic rehabilitation treatment, and referrals to support organizations. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of providing comprehensive information and services for children with hearing loss, including family support, training, and medical evaluations by qualified providers. The curr_chunk discusses medical interventions for hearing loss and related conditions, as well as screening procedures for newborns, infants, and young children up to age three. It also authorizes appropriations for statewide screening, evaluation, and intervention programs. The curr_chunk authorizes appropriations for technical assistance, data management, and research for various health agencies for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. The curr_chunk specifies that subsection (b)(2) should be funded using authorized funds for the purpose stated.
